awd_titl_txt: Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics for English Language Learners (STEMELL) Program at Lehman College
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is preparing science and mathematics teachers for high-need middle and high schools by offering extensive support at both undergraduate and graduate levels with a special focus on teaching English language learners (ELLs) in mainstream mathematics and science classrooms. Over the five-year project, the STEMELL Program is admitting three cohorts of 8 pre-service secondary mathematics and science teachers each, who progress through a three-year program: 2014-17, 2015-18 and 2016-19. Students are recruited from Lehman College's undergraduate population of mathematics or science majors.

ELLs represent a growing population in U.S. schools. Nationally, estimates are that by the year 2030, 40% of the school-aged population will consist of ELLs.  In New York City (NYC), 42.2% of students speak a language other than English at home with some classrooms consisting of 100% ELLs or former ELLs, who still have issues with the development of language and content. The percentage of students scoring below the basic level in mathematics and reading is higher among ELL students than among non-ELL students in grades 4 and 8.  Presently, there are no expectations regarding teacher preparedness for providing instruction in classrooms for English language learners. Most teachers graduate with a teaching certification but do not have any substantive training or experience in working effectively with ELLs in mainstream classrooms. The preparation of mathematics and science teachers who can provide effective instruction in these content areas to meet the ELLs classroom needs is therefore crucial in addressing these issues.

Preparing STEMELL pre-service Noyce teachers to meet the challenges of urban teaching in high-need schools, each cohort progresses through a 5 year BA/MA teacher preparation program.  Beginning in the junior year as scholars, the sequence leads to a BA in mathematics or science, NYS Initial Certification to teach mathematics or science in grades 7-12 and a Master's degree in Science of Education.  The program also offers additional advanced courses required for an extension in TESOL or bilingual education along with internships during the first two years, collaboration with middle and high school mathematics, science and TESOL teachers for the first two years, and full mentoring in the third year during the Noyce Scholars' first year of teaching in the NYC public schools.

inst.inst_name: Research Foundation Of The City University Of New York (Lehman)
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Research Foundation of CUNY on behalf of Lehman College

por.por_cntn:
In 2021, Lehman College of the City University of New York (CUNY) completed its seventh, and final, year of implementation of its Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics for English Language Learners (STEMELL). While originally intended to be a five-year grant, the program received three years of no-cost extensions, the last two due to the effects of Covid-19, for a total of eight program years (one planning year and seven implementation years). Implementation of STEMELL was multifaceted. It included rigorous mathematics, science, and education coursework, four different levels of internships of over 250 hours during four semesters at a Bronx high school for newcomers and a middle school under the guidance of teacher mentors from each of the two partnering schools. Scholars attended Saturday seminars, and were given direct support through mentorship opportunities, availability of project staff who facilitate access to resources, and support with job placements.

 

Twenty-one Scholars have completed the program, received certification, and have been teaching fulltime in high need schools. STEMELL redesigned Scholars' program of study to integrate data-wise knowledge and skills to inform instruction that was responsive to school priorities, NYCDOE requirements and initiatives. They learned valuable lessons about ways to foster culturally responsive classrooms, finding the right approach to organizing units, creating and delivering lessons, time management, working with colleagues and co-teachers, learning how to engage students, managing expectations and specific strategies useful in the work with MLL students.

 

As a result, Scholars became highly confident in tackling the challenges of teaching all students, but especially MLLs in mainstream classrooms, raised their ability to teach Science to MLLs, to meet the needs of MLLs, to collaborate with other teachers of MLL and to increase the English proficiency of the MLLs. Data collected through the Lehman College Observation System (LCOS), Scholar surveys, and interviews revealed that STEMELL Scholars demonstrated strong instructional skills once they began working with middle and high school students in the public schools. They demonstrated proficiency across all instructional effectiveness indicators of the LCOS, receiving high scores related to the quality of their lessons, their ability to deliver instruction to MLLs, their use of inquiry-based pedagogy, and the extent to which their lessons were student-centered.

 

Consequently, the department of Middle and High School Education adopted the STEMELL approach and developed a similar clinically-rich model in which learning the applications and practice on the field precedes the learning of the theoretical foundations in coursework.  The department designed two new clinical courses that offer similar experiences.

 

Finally, the program demonstrated success in keeping its cohort participants on track for completing their baccalaureate and masters bearing coursework, passing their teacher certification exams, and teaching within NYC public schools, and most importantly, in schools in high-needs districts, many with high percentages of MLLs, in alignment with the goals of the program. Comparison data indicated that STEMELL was successful in accelerating the trajectory of Scholars in their completion of course credits during their window of participation. Data on Cohorts 1-3 indicate that they obtained a greater number of credits, on average, than did other math and science education students in the same period and maintained higher GPAs.   


Last Modified: 12/29/2021
Modified by: Serigne M Gningue
